occurrences.line_text: After long paines and labours manifold,
Had past the paines of hell, and long enduring night.
He thence departing gaue for his paines hyre.
He could escape fowle death or deadly paines?
So double was his paines, so double be his prayse.
Behold, Ã´ man, that toilesome paines doest take
Yet no man for them taketh paines or care,
Yet no man to them can his carefull paines compare.
And euery feend his busie paines applide,
But each his paines to others profit still employd.
So end of that Carles dayes, and his owne paines did make.
After long wayes and perilous paines endured,
Could iudge what paines do louing harts perplexe.
Which thousand sprights with long enduring paines
Which alwayes of his paines he made the chiefest meed.
The fearefull damzell, with incessant paines:
She gracious Lady, yet no paines did spare,
What is there else, but cease these fruitlesse paines,
Or paines in loue, or punishments in hell;
Wouldst gather faine, and yet no paines wouldst take:
And saue her honour with your ventrous paines;
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
That did her passed paines in quiet rest assoyle.
Whom seeking euer since with endlesse paines,
Whilest I through paines and perlous ieopardie,
And for his paines a whistle him behight
The which for sparing litle cost or paines,
And learne to loue, by learning louers paines to rew.
Great shame to lose so long employed paines,
The present of his paines, that Monsters spoyle,
And twixt them both with parted paines did beare,
Of his large paines in her deliueraunce
So well he did his busie paines apply,
And for their paines obtaine of him a goodly meed.
But that same foole, which most increast her paines,
Great perill of his life, and restlesse paines did take.
Reaping eternall glorie of his restlesse paines.
Ne any paines ne perill did he shonne,
And all his paines did closely emulate;
Thence forward by that painfull way they pas,
Who seekes with painfull toile, shall honour soonest find.
A Painim knight, that well in armes was skild,
To make them to endure the pains, did them torment.
With piteous mone his percing speach gan paint;
Did paint his chearefull cheekes, yet being ded,
To paint it forth, him to displeasance moou'd,
Nor life-resembling pencill it can paint,
Were ruinous and old, but painted cunningly.
He shew'd him painted in a table plaine,
Will iudged be, and painted forgery,
And filles with flowres faire Floraes painted lap:
As Peacocke, that his painted plumes doth prancke,
She her gay painted plumes disorderid,
Did breath out bounteous smels, & painted colors shew.
Soone hearkned, and her painted bote streightway
No arboret with painted blossomes drest,
Decked with diuerse plumes, like painted Iayes,
His painted nimble wings, and vanisht quite away.
Were painted faire with memorable gestes,
The painted flowres, the trees vpshooting hye,
Her bow and painted quiuer, had vnlaste
There was he painted full of burning darts,
But painted plumes, in goodly order dight,
Yet was that all but painted, and purloynd,
And on her legs she painted buskins wore,
Would neuer more delight in painted show
Ne Poets wit, that passeth Painter farre
Her goodly bow, which paints the liquid ayre;
No faith so fast (quoth she) but flesh does paire.
And by her side there sate a gentle paire
That forward paire she euer would asswage,
So forth they pas, a well consorted paire,
And that gay paire issuing on the shore
An huge great paire of bellowes, which did styre
The constant paire heard all, that he did say,
So bene they gone yfeare, a wanton paire
Marcht in one rancke, yet an vnequall paire:
A paire of Pincers in his hand he had,
That euill matched paire they seemd to bee:
By that the louely paire drew nigh to hond:
A paire of redwhot yron tongs did take
An huge great paire of ballance in his hand,
These paires of friends in peace and setled rest,
And dimmed sight with pale and deadly hew
As ashes pale of hew and seeming ded;
And siluer Cynthia wexed pale and faint,
And sad to view his visage pale and wan,
Thus as he spake, his visage wexed pale,
And troubled bloud through his pale face was seene
Through inward feare, and seeming pale and faint
With lips full pale and foltring tongue opprest,
As pale and wan as ashes was his looke,
Spoild of their rosie red, were woxen pale and wan.
And with pale eyes fast fixed on the rest,
As ashes pale of hew, and wingyheeld;
Trembling in heart, and looking pale and wan,
And through long fasting woxen pale and wan,
And kissing oft his visage pale and wan.
Her lips were like raw lether, pale and blew,
That other swayne, like ashes deadly pale,
So shew'd them her, to proue how pale & weake she was.
She is ybrought vnto a paled greene,
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
Now hight Palemon, and is saylers frend;
And heauie sat vpon her palfrey slow:
Her wanton palfrey all was ouerspred
And to her snowy Palfrey got againe,
Her from her Palfrey pluckt, her visage to behold.
Vpon a milk-white Palfrey all alone,
And on a Palfrey rides more white then snow,
And her white Palfrey hauing conquered
Her wearie Palfrey closely, as she might,
And her flit Palfrey did so well apply
He set vpon her Palfrey tired lame,
The Palfrey, whereon she did trauell, slew,
A Damzell, flying on a palfrey fast
And would on her owne Palfrey him haue eased,
Haling her palfrey by the hempen raines.
She from her palfrey lighted on the plaine,
Vpon that milke-white Palfreyes carkas fed,
And after him Sir Paliumord forth prest,
As faire Aurora in her purple pall,
He gaue her gold and purple pall to weare,
And robd of royall robes, and purple pall,
In a long purple pall, whose skirt with gold,
Their furious encounter, and their fiercenesse pall.
His Lyons skin chaungd to a pall of gold,
The which she couering with her purple pall
A stately Pallace built of squared bricke,
Of her, that was the Lady of that Pallace bright.
Returnd to stately pallace of dame Pride;
And after to his Pallace he them brings,
Heard sound through all the Pallace pleasantly,
To pleasures pallace; it may soone be spide,
But all those pleasant bowres and Pallace braue,
When to Ioues pallace she doth take her way;
They to Mercillaes pallace come,
Where they a stately pallace did behold,
Vnto the pallace, where their kings did rayne,
My pallaces possessed of my foe,
For her great worth; she Palladine is hight:
So soone as Night had with her pallid hew
Gainst which the pallid death findes no defence.
Her heart does quake, and deadly pallid hew
A comely Palmer, clad in blacke attire,
Palmer, (him answered the Redcrosse knight)
With his blacke Palmer, that him guided still.
Then turning to his Palmer said, Old syre
Palmer (quoth he) death is an equall doome
Whom thus at gaze, the Palmer gan to bord
Vptaking, to the Palmer gaue to beare;
There this old Palmer shewed himselfe that day,
His Palmer now shall foot no more alone:
With that blacke Palmer, his most trusty guide;
Which when the Palmer saw, he loudly cryde,
Then gan the Palmer thus, most wretched man,
Madman (said then the Palmer) that does seeke
Till that the Palmer, by his graue restraint,
But the Blacke Palmer suffred still to stond,
In Mammons house, the Palmer, whom whyleare
The Palmer lent his eare vnto the noyce,
Whom when the Palmer saw, abasht he was
The Palmer seeing his left empty place,
Now bene they come, whereas the Palmer sate,
To whom the Palmer fearelesse answered;
Then said Cymochles; Palmer, thou doest dote,
Faire Sir, said then the Palmer suppliaunt,
Then turning to the Palmer, he gan spy
Said he then to the Palmer, Reuerend syre,
Not one, nor other, (said the Palmer graue)
Palmer, (said he) no knight so rude, I weene,
Whom when the Palmer saw in such distresse,
But when the Palmer, whom he long ygoe
Of my good sword and shield? The Palmer glad,
Which to auenge, the Palmer him forth drew
With him the Palmer eke in habit sad,
Said then the Boteman, Palmer stere aright,
The Palmer seeing them in safetie past,
Till that the Palmer gan full bitterly
Therefore, Sir Palmer, keepe an euen hand;
Feare nought, (then said the Palmer well auiz'd;)
Which Guyon hearing, streight his Palmer bad,
But him the Palmer from that vanity,
Said then the Palmer, Lo where does appeare
And his sage Palmer, that him gouerned;
The Palmer ouer them his staffe vpheld,
Such vertue in his staffe had eke this Palmer sage.
On which when gazing him the Palmer saw,
When thus the Palmer; Now Sir, well auise;
The noble Elfe, and carefull Palmer drew
The skilfull Palmer formally did frame.
But them the Palmer soone did pacify.
But Palmer, if it mote thee so aggrate,
To whom the Palmer thus, The donghill kind
Which when his Palmer saw, he gan to feare
Weake wretch I wrapt my selfe in Palmers weed,
Guyon, by Palmers gouernance,
Those mighty palmes, the which ye wont t'embrew
The shaking Palsey, and Saint Fraunces fire:
Did sit, as yet ashamd, how rude Pan did her dight.
Or Panachï¿½a, or Polygony,
And fragrant violets, and Pances trim,
Whiles the sad pang approching she does feele,
The lesser pangs can beare, who hath endur'd the chiefe.
The bitter pangs, that doth your heart infest.
And with most painefull pangs to sigh and sob,
His foltring toung with pangs of drerinesse,
And pangs of death her spirit ouertooke.
Such were this Ladies pangs and dolorous assay.
And gentle pangues, with which he maked meeke
Smote him so rudely on the Pannikell,
Saue one old Nymph, hight Panope to keepe it cleane.
And Panope her entertaind eke well,
And Panopï¿½, and wise Protomedï¿½a,
Yet might her pitteous hart be seene to pant and quake.
Which all that while she felt to pant and quake,
And pant with hope of that aduentures hap:
And hinder him from libertie to pant:
Panthea, seemd the brightest thing, that was:
Who all of Christall did Panthea build:
The spotted Panther, and the tusked Bore,
That life nigh crusht out of his panting brest:
He soone approched, panting, breathlesse, whot,
Then panting soft, and trembling euerie ioynt,
Panting for breath, and almost out of hart,
Abate, and panting breath begin to fayle,
Which from Alcluid to Panwelt did that border bound.
From mothers pap I taken was vnfit:
By great Dame Nature, from whose fruitfull pap
I taken was from nourses tender pap,
Which he disclosing, red thus, as the paper spake.
Her vomit full of bookes and papers was,
Whether in Paphos, or Cytheron hill,
Much more then that, which was in Paphos built,
Phidias did make in Paphos Isle of yore,
Her daintie paps; which like young fruit in May
And her two lilly paps aloft displayd,
Some praise her paps, some praise her lips and nose;
Her paps, which like white silken pillowes were,
There the most daintie Paradise on ground,
Saue in this Paradise, be heard elswhere:
Right in the middest of that Paradise,
He seemed brought to bed in Paradise,
It seem'd a second paradise to ghesse,
As it an earthly Paradize had beene:
In Paradize whilome did plant this flowre,
She brought her to her ioyous Paradize,
Whose prowesse paragon saw neuer liuing wight.
With his faire paragon, his conquests part,
Hauing so peerelesse paragon ygot:
Then next ensew'd the Paragon to see
Of all on earth, and made a matchlesse paragon.
Performd, in paragone of proudest men:
Of grace and beautie noble Paragone,
Offend the good: for good by paragone
Alone he rode without his Paragone;
She had them made a paragone to be,
Of both their beauties to make paragone,
To be a Princes Paragone esteemed,
Some of their pride, some paragons disdayning,
The fayrest Ladie was adiudgd for Paramore.
No solace could her Paramour intreat,
Franckly each paramour his leman knowes,
Her fayned Paramour, her forced guest,
And wooed him her paramour to bee:
Which of my loue was partner Paramoure:
The Flowre-deluce, her louely Paramoure,
Courted of many a iolly Paramoure,
Begotten by her kingly Paramoure,
The loue of Venus and her Paramoure
And wooed him her Paramoure to be;
Was of himselfe the idle Paramoure;
Making her seeke an vnknowne Paramoure,
Fresh Hyacinthus, Phoebus paramoure,
This crafty Paramoure, and now it plaine displayd.
To visite her beloued Paramoure,
Each one profest to be her paramoure,
Complayning of her cruell Paramoure,
Impatient of any paramoure:
And decks the girlonds of her paramoures,
The Willow worne of forlorne Paramours,
The heauie losse of their braue Paramours,
They all doe learne to play the Paramours;
(Both two her paramours, both by her hyred,
Of many a Ladie, and many a Paramowre:
If chaunce I him encounter parauaunt;
That in the midst was placed parauaunt,
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
Some made in books, some in long parchme[n]t scrolles,
The Pardale swift, and the Tigre cruell;
Pardon the errour of enraged wight,
Therefore I ought craue pardon, till I there haue beene.
O pardon me, my soueraigne Lord, to show
The which O pardon me thus to enfold
O pardon, and vouchsafe with patient eare
But for this carkasse pardon I entreat,
If it be I, of pardon I you pray;
Thus farre forth pardon, sith that choicest wit
So be ye pleasd to pardon all amis.
Pardon I pray my heedlesse ouersight,
Of pardon for the strife, which late befell
And pardon simple man, that rash did him displease.
I pardon yield, and with thy rudenesse beare;
Then pardon, O most sacred happie spirit,
I me submit, and you of pardon pray,
And pardon her besought his errour frayle,
But her of pardon prayd more earnestlie,
T'asswage his wrath, and pardon their mesprise.
Pardon the boldnesse of thy basest thrall,
Saying, Sir Knight, of pardon I you pray,
And often treat for pardon and remission
Then pardon me, most dreaded Soueraine,
And pardon crau'd for his so rash assault,
Pardon thy shepheard, mongst so many layes,
But gentle Shepheard pardon thou my shame,
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
And all sixe brethren, borne of one parent,
The image of his monstrous parent Geryone.
That parentage, with pride so did she swell,
The which was borne of noble parentage,
And many a Lord of noble parentage,
Inquyrd, which of them most did loue her parentage.
And after gan inquire his parentage,
That lou'd a Ladie of high parentage;
Which from great Neptune do deriue their parentage.
Though of meane parentage and kindred base,
Whose parents deare, whilest equall destinies
That Parents deare from tyrants powre deliuer might.
That to redeeme thy woefull parents head,
To thinke of those her captiue Parents deare,
The brasen towre in which my parents deare
That O my parents might I happily
Then to thy lucklesse parents did befall:
And in dead parents balefull ashes bred,
Whose wofull parents she hath wickedly fordonne.
T'auenge his Pare[n]ts death on them, that had it wrought.
Accord of friends, consent of parents sought,
Then either care of parents could refraine,
For all the rest of those two parents came,
His auncient parents, namely th'auncient Thame.
her parents vnderstands:
To Paridas his sonne.
Lo there Sir Paridel, for your desart,
Whom when as Paridel more plaine beheld,
Then that which he had to Sir Paridel resynd.
For thy, he thus to Paridel bespake,
Ah Sir (said Paridel) do not dismay
Is sought by Paridell.
That Paridell it was. Tho to him yode,
Which words when Paridell had heard, his hew
Aye me, (said Paridell) the signes be sad,
Paridell giusts with Britomart:
The cause, why Satyrane and Paridell
Then is he not more mad (said Paridell)
That counsell pleasd: then Paridell did rise,
Then Paridell began to chaunge his theme,
But chiefly Paridell his hart did grate,
But Paridell sore brused with the blow,
And Paridell though partly discontent
Was her before, and Paridell besyde;
But his blind eye, that syded Paridell,
Then Paridell, in whom a kindly pryde
From whom I Paridell by kin descend;
The ruefull story of Sir Paridell,
Ah fairest Lady knight, (said Paridell)
Betwixt vs both vnknowne. So ended Paridell.
Paridell rapeth Hellenore:
But Paridell complaynd, that his late fight
But Paridell kept better watch, then hee,
So perfect in that art was Paridell,
The iolly Paridell, for all his paine.
Whom, to be Paridell he did deuize;
They spide, where Paridell came pricking fast
And eke Sir Paridell, all were he deare;
Soone as the old man saw Sir Paridell,
I take no keepe of her (said Paridell)
Faithlesse Duessa, and false Paridell,
Paridell for her striues,
And Paridell her scornd, and set at nought,
That to Sir Paridell these words he sent;
But Paridell that had too late a tryall
And shewing her, did Paridell vpbray;
So fortune friends the bold: whom Paridell
Yet Paridell him enuied therefore,
Too foolish Paridell, that fayrest floure
Fond Squire, full angry then sayd Paridell,
And you Sir Blandamour and Paridell,
Stird vp twixt Scudamour and Paridell,
Gainst whom Sir Paridell himselfe addrest,
Vnto whose rescue forth rode Paridell;
And after her did Paridell produce
Ne lesse thereat did Paridell complaine,
And at them both Sir Paridell did loure.
Loue-lauish Blandamour, and lustfull Paridell.
But Paridell of loue did make no threasure,
For sometimes Paridell and Blandamour
For Paridell did take to Druons side,
And Paridell and Druon fiercely laid
With faithlesse Blandamour and Paridell,
Till partiall Paris dempt it Venus dew,
Sir Paris far renowmd through noble fame,
Through which, when Paris brought his famous prise
On Phrygian Paris by Plexippus brooke,
She of his Father Parius did name;
The second was Parlante, a bold knight,
And lacke of reskewes will to parley driue;
And Peece, that vnto parley eare will giue,
And soone into a goodly Parlour brought,
Or sweet Parnasse, the haunt of Muses faire;
Ye sacred imps, that on Parnasso dwell,
And with them sayling thence, to th'Isle of Paros came.
That was by him cald Paros, which before
Who soone him brought into a secret part,
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
And now he to her brought part of his stolen things.
Till they be come vnto the furthest part:
In which sad ï¿½sculapius farre a part
Did heale them all againe, and ioyned euery part.
And euery tender part for feare does shake:
The better part now of the lingring day,
And euery tender part does tosse and turne:
Who hath endur'd the whole, can beare each part.
In heauenly mercies hast thou not a part?
Which for my part I couet to performe,
That of the world least part to vs is red:
Or cursed hand hath plaid this cruell part,
And makes it seruant to her basest part:
But still when Guyon came to part their fight,
And drew his deadly weapon, to maintain his part.
And for my part I vow, dissembled not a whit.
And staynd their prayses with thy least good part;
Where left, he went, and his owne false part playd,
Would oftentimes emongst them beare a part,
As to despise so courteous seeming part,
And yield him readie passage to that other part.
To th'vpper part, where was aduaunced hye
And lower part did reach to lowest Hell;
And part triangulare, Ã´ worke diuine;
But Albanact had all the Northrene part,
Which through the world the[m] swarmd in euery part,
To haue a pere in part of soueraintie,
The Churches part, and Ploughmans portion,
Where each might best offend his proper part,
And let him heare some part of their rare melody.
And form'd so liuely in each perfect part
But liuing art may not least part expresse,
And him in euery part before her fashioned.
Yet him in euery part before she knew,
Yet playd Pasiphaï¿½ a more monstrous part,
How like a Gyaunt in each manly part
At last their wayes so fell, that they mote part
Searching all lands and each remotest part,
Madnesse to saue a part, and lose the whole.
As percing leuin, which the inner part
Which knitting their rancke braunches part to part,
Which knitting their rancke braunches part to part,
Fashiond aboue within their inmost part,
Tyde with her broken girdle, it a part
And with Latinus did the kingdome part.
And euery part to safety full sound,
With his faire paragon, his conquests part,
Which was not yet so secret, but some part
Where is my part then of this Ladie bright,
Now stood, came forth in hast to take his part,
Then gan the part of Chalengers anew
Tho gan he swell in euery inner part,
Yet is not this the first vnknightly part,
And lashing dreadfully at euery part,
With Beares and Tygers taking heauie part,
He part of his small feast to her would share;
Her spightfull words did pricke, & wound the inner part.
To whom he did diuide part of his purchast spoile.
And each one taking part in others aide,
The warlike Dame was on her part assaid,
Art playing second natures part, supplyed it.
That vnto euery person knew her part;
And there his mortall part by great mischance
T'expresse some part of that great equipage,
Where searching euery part, her well assured,
He would to his owne part restore the same againe.
What was the poyse of euery part of yore:
The most part of my land hath washt away,
Vnto your part, and pluckt from his away,
That part of Iustice, which is Equity,
But Talus mote not be admitted to her part.
Or to his part allures, and bribeth vnder hand.
Playing his pages part, as he had beene
That Ladies part, and to the Souldan lout:
On either part, she placed th'one on th'one,
And with him to make part against her, came
But then for her, on the contrarie part,
And woxe inclined much vnto her part,
To weeten Mercie, be of Iustice part,
Oft spilles the principall, to saue the part;
That Tyrants part, with close or open ayde,
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
And wish, that he part of his spoyle might share.
My loues owne part to leaue so suddenly,
But wayt on him in euery place and part.
